spend.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to use your money to pay for goods or services
spend.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: I can’t afford to spend any more money this week.
The repairs cost a lot, but it’s money well spent (=a sensible way of spending money).
I only want to spend about $20.
More money should be spent on education.
Mum never spends any money on herself.
spend.translation[0].definitions[0].note: I don’t spend much on clothes
I don’t spend much for clothes
spend.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to use time doing a particular thing or pass time in a particular place
spend.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: I want to spend more time with my family.
We’ll have to spend the night in a hotel.
His childhood was spent in Brazil.
Stacey spends all her free time painting.
spend.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to stay for the night and have sex with someone
spend.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: if someone spends the night at someone’s house, they sleep at that person’s house for a night
spend.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: She spent the night at a friend’s house.
spend.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to use effort or energy to do something
spend.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: I love to cook, but I don’t feel like spending the energy every evening.
spend.translation[0].note_box[0].section: spend
to use money to buy things
I bought two skirts and a T-shirt and I only spent $50.
How much do you spend a week on food?
go through something
to spend all of an amount of money over a period of time – used especially when saying that someone spends a lot of money
I got through all my money in less than a month, and had to get my parents to send me more.
go to great expense
to spend a lot of money in order to do something, because you think it is important or special
The party was wonderful – they had obviously gone to great expense.
There’s no need to go to great expense.
squander
to waste money on unnecessary things, instead of saving it or using it carefully
His son had squandered the family fortune on gambling and women.
splash out
to spend a lot of money on something you really want or will enjoy
Let’s splash out on a bottle of champagne.
People often splash out for Christmas and then regret it later.
blow
to spend a lot of money on something, especially on something that you do not really need
Her husband blew all their savings on a new sports car.
economize
to spend less money
We’re trying to economize by eating at home instead of going out for meals.
spend.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: the amount of money spent by a company, organization, or person on something – used especially in business
spend.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: I was just totting up our advertising spend in the last four or five weeks.
spend.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to use your money to buy or pay for things
spend.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: How much do we have to spend?
It is worth spending money on advertising.
spend.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Effective managers spend time getting to know their workers.
I have spent the past seven years working in industry.
spend.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: the amount of money spent by a company on a particular activity in a particular period of time
spend.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: They increased the marketing spend needed to launch the new brands.
